channel.title: WWDC21 on Fresh Swift
channel.description: Recent content in WWDC21 on Fresh Swift

item.title: Getting Started with async/await in SwiftUI
item.description: Swift's new concurrency model continues to be one of the most popular topics amongst the developer community. There have already been many great articles written on the topic, but I still enjoy reading more about it, as it helps cement understanding. In this post, Peter Friese helps us get started with async/await, demonstrating how it interacts with SwiftUI and its latest features.

item.title: Table and Collection View Cells Reload Improvements in iOS 15
item.description: iOS 15 includes several new APIs that help to make UICollectionViews and UITableViews more performant. In this post, Lee Kah Seng from Swift Senpai demonstrates how to use these APIs via a fully working sample project.

item.title: What's new in Swift 5.5?
item.description: Swift 5.5, available in any Xcode 13 beta, includes a huge number of changes to the language. At WWDC this year, a lot of these changes were covered by session videos. However, despite being published before WWDC, this in-depth article from Paul Hudson is still worth a read. Paul walks through most of the language changes introduced in Swift 5.5, with code samples for each. Lot's to cover here.

item.title: AsyncImage in SwiftUI
item.description: New in iOS 15 is AsyncImage, a new SwiftUI View for fetching and displaying remote images from a URL. Here, Gabriel Theodoropoulos demonstrates how to use this new type, and highlights some of its pros and cons.

item.title: What is new in SwiftUI after WWDC21
item.description: SwiftUI took another substantial and welcomed step forward this year at WWDC. Along with some expected improvements, such as the new refreshable ViewModifier, we also saw some less anticipated additions such as the new TimeLine View type. In this post, Majid Jabrayilov provides his summary of significant SwiftUI additions announced at WWDC21.

item.title: Core Store
item.description: Core Data is an object graph and persistence framework provided by Apple. Introduced in iOS 3.0, it's still relevant but is also generally acknowledged as not being particularly Swift friendly. In this post, the excellent Daniel Steinberg makes an early prediction for a Swift replacement of Core Data which he thinks might be unveiled at this year's WWDC.
